Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Economical Fabrication of Bulk Metallic Glass Sheets through Roll-Stretching
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is in enabling wide range of commercial applications of bulk metallic glasses (BMG). BMGs are novel metallic materials that are fundamentally different from, and advantageous to conventional alloys. They are stronger than most crystalline metals, but at the same time shapeable like plastics. Additional benefits of BMGs include extremely high precision of parts, increased complexity and elimination of expensive machining. Use of BMGs will provide broad opportunities for manufacturers in areas such as watch making and precision mechanics, electronics, biomedical, nano-imprint, defense, aerospace, and automotive. The current barrier to industrializing BMGs is non-availability of practical feedstock material such as BMG sheets. Technologies that we are developing as part of this project include BMG sheet fabrication and thermoplastic forming (TPF) of final components for a variety of applications. Using sheets, manufacturers can leverage BMGs unique processability to fabricate complex shapes at highest precision and ease through thermoplastic forming methods. Our technology also has significant societal implications. It will empower innovative small and medium size U.S. companies by bringing them a novel manufacturing technology that is highly versatile, energy efficient and low in capital investment.



This project is based on the recent scientific discovery of BMG sheet fabrication using the thermoplastic forming technology. This is a low-force, high-rate deformation method with great potential for large-scale commercial manufacturing. We expect that our findings will lead to a better understanding of TPF-based processes. Specifically, for multi-step TPF-based sheet fabrication, the proposed work will reveal process stability and how it is affected by processing parameters. Proposed research will also determine the effects of TPF-based processing on mechanical properties of BMGs, will help identify suitable BMG alloys for sheet fabrication and provide insights into their commercial feasibility. In addition, the proposed work will also enhance theoretical understanding of BMG sheet fabrication and help develop a predictable and quantitative model description. Such models can allow prediction of alloy-specific processing conditions in industrial settings in the future. Finally, this project will result in a commercially viable sheet fabrication process and apparatus for BMG sheets of unprecedented sizes. It will significantly advance opportunities for bulk metallic glasses in a wide range of applications, bringing two decades of academic discoveries to the commercial arena.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Supercool Metals focuses on bulk metallic glasses, BMGs, a new class of materials with exciting properties that typically exceed those of even best structural alloys. These properties are paired with unusual processability that can be best compared to thermoplastics. However, to unleash the full potential of BMGs and specifically the versatile thermoplastic forming (TPF) techniques, commercially available BMG sheets are required. Technologically, fabricating BMG sheets is entirely different than fabricating sheets of crystalline (conventional) metals. Supercool Metals’ focus on the BMG sheet technology will enable broad industrial BMG applications. Within Phase II of this SBIR project, we have designed, built, and optimized a commercial machine to fabricate metallic glass sheets under commercially viable and energy efficient conditions and matured the BMG forming technology to the next level.

A particular focus in the design criteria of the equipment has been on the ability to realize a stable and robust sheet forming process and to fabricate large size BMG sheets, up to 2-3 feet in size, at high quality under commercially viable conditions. This main technical goal has been fully accomplished. We demonstrated fabrication of BMG sheets of unprecedented sizes using our designed equipment and showed the potential to further increase sheet dimensions and to scale up production equipment. Fabrication time that we achieved is less than one minute, and the entire process is done in air. As part of this project, we fabricated BMG sheets with thickness uniformity, mechanical properties, crystallinity and other aspects within pre-defined specs. This is a significant technological achievement in the field of bulk metallic glasses.

This project was very important for the development of a wider ecosphere of the BMG industry, as it demonstrated the potential for a large scale production of various types of BMG products with high consistency in product properties. It is a paradigm-shifting materials and processing technology that brought two decades of academic discoveries to the commercial arena. We are already using this technology for prototype production of complex parts and we are seeing a rapid growth of opportunities for the BMG sheet technology based on achievements in this project.

Supercool Metals’ technology has far-reaching implications on the metal manufacturing industry overall for two main reasons. TPF represents energy efficient, green fabrication of metal components and it can enable decentralized manufacturing of high-tech products for local U.S. companies. Large scale manufacturing using conventional metals has been mainly centralized outside the U.S. and has been difficult to integrate into other regions. However, TPF-based BMG processing with its low capital cost offers a new opportunity for the U.S. manufacturers, even for small size companies. It presents a real potential to set-up decentralized high-tech metal manufacturing in the U.S.

Modified by: Evgenia Pekarskaya
